kou commented on pull request #5061: ARROW-6203: [GLib] Add garrow_array_argsort()
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5061#discussion_r313156275
 
 

 ##########
 File path: c_glib/arrow-glib/compute.cpp
 ##########
 @@ -1448,6 +1448,35 @@ garrow_array_is_in(GArrowArray *left,
   }
 }
 
+/**
+ * garrow_array_argsort:
+ * @array: A #GArrowArray.
+ * @error: (nullable): Return location for a #GError or %NULL.
+ *
+ * Returns: (nullable) (transfer full): The indices that would sort
+ *   an array on success, %NULL on error.
+ *
+ * Since: 0.15.0
+ */
+GArrowArray *
+garrow_array_argsort(GArrowArray *array,
 
 Review comment:
   How about using other name than "argsort" because "argsort" isn't consistent with our existing API?
   
     * We use "_" as word separator in function name.
     * We don't use abbreviated name as much as possible.
   
   "argsort" is familiar to NumPy users because NumPy uses "argsort": https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.argsort.html
   
   But "argsort" isn't widely name outside of NumPy.
   
   For example, R uses "order": https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/fullrefman.pdf#Rfn.order
   
   MATLAB's "sort" returns sorted array and indices to sort array: https://mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/sort.html
   
   Here are candidates of this function name from me:
   
     1. `order`: Like R
     2. `sort`: Like MATLAB but doesn't return sorted array itself.
     3. `sort_index`: Add suffix for `sort` variable. This is our API naming rule that adds suffix for variant.
     4. `non_materialized_sort`: We used "non-materializing sort" in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-1566 . It well describes but it's a bit long.
         * Or `sort_non_materialized`
   
   In my opinion: 4 -> 3 -> 1 -> 2
   
   @shiro615 @mrkn What do you think about this?
   
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

+garrow_array_argsort(GArrowArray *array,
 
 Review comment:
   I think `non_materialized_sort` is better.
   I think `sort_index` is also good, but pandas's `sort_index`(`pandas.DataFrame.sort_index`) returns the sorted data frame itself.

 Review comment:

mrkn commented on pull request #5061: ARROW-6203: [GLib] Add garrow_array_argsort()
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5061#discussion_r313197115
 
 

 ##########
 File path: c_glib/arrow-glib/compute.cpp
 ##########
 @@ -1448,6 +1448,35 @@ garrow_array_is_in(GArrowArray *left,
   }
 }
 
+/**
+ * garrow_array_argsort:
+ * @array: A #GArrowArray.
+ * @error: (nullable): Return location for a #GError or %NULL.
+ *
+ * Returns: (nullable) (transfer full): The indices that would sort
+ *   an array on success, %NULL on error.
+ *
+ * Since: 0.15.0
+ */
+GArrowArray *
+garrow_array_argsort(GArrowArray *array,
 
 Review comment:
   I suspect that `argsort` came from `argmax`. Julia also has argmax, but doesn’t have argsort. Instead, it has [sortperm](https://pkg.julialang.org/docs/julia/THl1k/1.1.1/base/sort.html#Base.sortperm) for the feature of numpy’s argsort.
   
   I'm unconfident that `non_materialized_sort` is good for this feature because of the following two reasons. (1) `non_materialized_sort` is too long.  (2) I'm not sure that "non-materialized" intuitively means "making a sorted index array".  The meaning of "materialize" is similar to "appear".  So "non-materialized sort" tells us it doesn't make a sorted value array, but it doesn't say that it makes a sorted index array.
   
   I propose that the new candidate: `sort(index: false)`.  This is short and intuitive.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

   I suspect that `argsort` came from `argmax`. Julia also has argmax, but doesn’t have argsort. Instead, it has [sortperm](https://pkg.julialang.org/docs/julia/THl1k/1.1.1/base/sort.html#Base.sortperm) for the feature of numpy’s argsort.  So, I think avoiding `argsort` is good.
   
   I'm unconfident that `non_materialized_sort` is good for this feature because of the following two reasons. (1) `non_materialized_sort` is too long.  (2) I'm not sure that "non-materialized" intuitively means "making a sorted index array".  The meaning of "materialize" is similar to "appear".  So "non-materialized sort" tells us it doesn't make a sorted value array, but it doesn't say that it makes a sorted index array.
   
   I propose that the new candidate: `sort(index: false)`.  This is short and intuitive.

 Review comment:
   The disadvantage of switching return value by argument is that the type of a return value is different by the argument.
   
   Providing both `sort_values` and `sort_indicies` doesn’t introduce the ambiguity of the return value.

kou commented on pull request #5061: ARROW-6203: [GLib] Add garrow_array_argsort()
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5061#discussion_r313705325
 
 

 ##########
 File path: c_glib/arrow-glib/compute.cpp
 ##########
 @@ -1448,6 +1448,35 @@ garrow_array_is_in(GArrowArray *left,
   }
 }
 
+/**
+ * garrow_array_argsort:
+ * @array: A #GArrowArray.
+ * @error: (nullable): Return location for a #GError or %NULL.
+ *
+ * Returns: (nullable) (transfer full): The indices that would sort
+ *   an array on success, %NULL on error.
+ *
+ * Since: 0.15.0
+ */
+GArrowArray *
+garrow_array_argsort(GArrowArray *array,
 
 Review comment:
   It's generally yes. But this is not occurred for this case because we have generic `GArrowArray` class. `sort_values()` returns `GArrowArray *` and `sort_indices()` returns `GArrowUInt64Array *`. But we can use `GArrowArray *` for `sort_indices()` too.
   
   If Arrow C++ accepts `SortIndices`, we'll use `GArrowUInt64Array *garrow_array_sort_indices()`.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
